Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

USEPA 40 CFR Part 68

Subpart G 



Introduction



The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations 40 CFR Part 68, require facilities that have a regulated substance above the listed threshold quantities to develop a formal Risk Management Program. The Michigan City Sanitary District (MCSD) maintains quantities of chlorine and sulfur dioxide above the RMP threshold quantity of 2,500 and 5,000 pounds, respectively, and as such, is subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. A hazard assessment or Offsite Consequences Analysis (OCA) of the worst-case scenarios and alternate case scenarios for chlorine and sulfur dioxide were completed which concluded that RMP program level 3 is applicable for MCSD's Disinfection Process.

  

Executive Summary Data Elements



According to EPA guidance the executive summary must include a brief description of the facility's Risk Management Program. The following sections list each of the required executive summary data elements by rule citation. In accordance with EPA guidance, the Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) is not covered in the executive summary. The format of the section corresponds to the executive summary data elements as described in 40 CFR Part 68 Executive Summary Section and the information presented is intended to describe the elements of MCSD's Risk Management Plan including RMP Prevention Program-Level 3 elements.  

 

68.155(a) Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies



The  Michigan City Sanitary District's SAFETY GOAL states that we will provide a workplace where safety and health are considered first and integrated into every part of our work by: Fostering a safety and health culture through collaboration and constructive dialogue among all levels of the organization; Continually improving our safety and health systems, programs and activities through results-oriented and action-based objectives; and  Personally, h

olding ourselves accountable to work safely as well as encouraging our coworkers to work safely. To achieve our SAFETY GOAL, objectives with achievable action plans are developed, implemented, and maintained among all departments.    

Wastewater Treatment Plant (J.B. Gifford WWTP) has operated their Disinfection Process (Chlorination & Sulfonation Systems) without an incident since the previous RMP submission. This successful operating record is due to the WWTP's commitment to effective management of the RMP elements. The Wastewater Treatment Facility has a management system organization that manages each RMP element within the Disinfection Process up to the discharge side of the Effluent Room Chlorination injectors and Sulfonation injectors as well as the discharge side of Stormwater Basin Chlorination injectors and Sulfonation injectors. At this point in the Disinfection Process, chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas are no longer present. A release of an aqueous chlorine solution or aqueous sulfur dioxide solution would not cause a catastrophic release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas.

68.155(b) Stationary Source and the Substance Handled



The Sanitary District of Michigan City, J.B Gifford Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) operates a 12-MGD municipal wastewater treatment plant (maximum capacity 15-MGD) in the City of Michigan City, Indiana to disinfect wastewater by the partial destruction of pathogenic microorganisms in the wastewater stream using chemical means. The WWTP uses an aqueous solution of chlorine (Cl2) to provide disinfection while dechlorination (sulfonation) is accomplished with an aqueous solution of sulfur dioxide (SO2) that reacts with chlorine residuals including mono- and dichloramine before the treated wastewater is discharged through NPDES Outfalls into Trail Creek. Michigan City WWTP provides continuous chlorination and dechlorination for treated water discharged at Outfall #001 from April 01 through October 31. Sand Filter Backwash Water is disinfected year-round and sulfur dioxide (SO2) is added as needed to dechlorinate the backwash water prior to discharge out of Outfall #001. Disinfection and dechlorination of Storm Basin discharge at Outfall #002 occurs from April 01 through October 31 during a significant weather (rain) event. 

The Disinfection Process is located within the perimeter fence line of the wastewater treatment plant site. A physical security protection system including access controls are in place to prevent unauthorized personnel from entering the Disinfection Process.  The WWTP maintains chlorine and sulfur dioxide leak detection devices within the Disinfection Process including the Gas Storage Room, Effluent Disinfection Room, and the Storm Basin Disinfection Room. There are audible and visual alarms for chlorine and sulfur dioxide to provide warning of a gas release. 

The Effluent Disinfection System and the Storm Basin Disinfection System are systems whereby chlorine a

nd sulfur dioxide gas are fed through injectors and combined with non-potable water to form aqueous solutions as chlorine and sulfur dioxide. A vacuum regulator is used to attach a chlorine container to the chlorination system. The same setup is used for the sulfur dioxide container.  A vacuum is created by the site's non-potable water feed system which draws chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas through the chlorine and sulfur dioxide injectors respectively.  This vacuum system provides an excellent mitigation measure that greatly minimizes the risk of a reportable gas release to the environment. If a chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas leak occurs anywhere in the system beyond the vacuum regulator that is attached to the 1-ton container in the Gas Storage Room, then vacuum is lost and the regulator automatically shuts-off gas flow at the container. Also, the vacuum regulator automatically shut-off gas flow at the container, if the non-potable water source is removed from the process.  

The inventory of chlorine and sulfur dioxide fluctuates throughout the year. As stated earlier, the Sanitary District's "Disinfection Season" begins April 01 and ends on October 31. Depending on weather and other factors, disinfection may begin before April 01 and extend beyond October 31. During this time, normal inventory in the Gas Storage Room is six (6) 1-ton chlorine containers and five (5) 1-ton sulfur dioxide containers. During the "Disinfection Season", a chlorine container is feeding gas and another container is on standby and connected to a vacuum regulator. When one chlorine container is near empty, the system automatically switches feed to the container on standby, thus provide continuous chlorination. The same system setup applies to the sulfur dioxide system to provide continuous dechlorination. The Stormwater Disinfection System has one (1) chlorine container and one (1) sulfur dioxide container on standby with the gas feed shutoff on each container. During the period between

early December and late February, the inventory is reduced to only two (2) sulfur dioxide containers and two (2) chlorine containers in the Gas Storage Room. A chlorine container and sulfur dioxide container are connected to the Effluent Room Disinfection System and provide gas feed to the Filter Backwash System. The Stormwater Disinfection System continues to have one (1) chlorine container and one (1) sulfur dioxide container on standby with the gas feed shutoff on each container. Gas inventories on site are carefully managed by operations, maintenance and purchasing. The maximum inventory in the Gas Storage Room is seven (7) 1-ton containers of chlorine and the maximum inventory for sulfur dioxide is six (6) 1-ton containers, but this would rarely if ever occur.





68.155(d) Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Prevention Program required for compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 for Program 3 processes aligns with the prevention program required under OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119-Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals. Sanitary District management aligned its Disinfection Process Prevention Program with Indiana OSHA PSM regulatory requirements in 2010. The Sanitary District's WWTP operations and maintenance employees are actively involved in the evaluation, review and updates of their prevention programs and safety-related procedures. WWTP operations and maintenance personnel along with Sanitary District management were actively involved in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) completed on September 22, 2021.  



68.155(e) Five-year Accident History



The chlorination and dechlorination facility has been in place since 1955. No accidents, as described under 40 CFR 68.42(a), have occurred at this facility since the last RMP submission on November 16, 2016.  



68.155(f) Emergency Response Program



The Sanitary District of Michigan City has implemented an Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38. Furthermore, the facility is inclu

ded in the La Porte County Community Emergency Response Plan. If a chemical release occurs in the Disinfection Process, employees are expected to follow the MCSD Emergency Action Plan including immediate notification of the La Porte County 911 Dispatch Center. Normally, Michigan City Fire Department would be first on-scene and assume command including initiation of any community emergency evacuation measures. All response agencies and resources follow FEMA's National Incident Management System Incident Command System protocols and guidelines. WWTP personnel assist responders by providing their technical knowledge of Disinfection Process equipment and operations.

 An emergency response tabletop exercise was completed on September 17, 2020, with scenarios involving the Disinfection Process. Exercise participants included Sanitary District operations, maintenance and management personnel, Michigan City Fire Department, Michigan City Police, Michigan City Mayor's Office, La Porte Co. HazMat Team, La Porte County Emergency Management Agency, Franciscan Alliance Hospital-Michigan City, and Alexander Chemical Corporation-Kingsbury Plant HazMat Team Specialist.

        

68.155(g) Safety Improvements



Suggestions for safety improvement are encouraged and evaluated through our employee participation programs and activities.  Improvements made in response to suggestions from our employees, contractors, or learnings from other WWTP sites are routinely considered. Periodic PSM and RMP audits are reviewed by management and action items are tracked to completion. Recommendations for the Disinfection Process are carefully evaluated and documented in accordance with PSM and RMP regulatory requirements. Contractor Safety, Training and Emergency Response Programs continue to be a strong program elements. Improvements have been made to the operator and maintenance procedures as well as the procedures covering Management of Change and the Mechanical Integrity Program.

on



As part of the Michigan City Sanitary District (J.B. Gifford) Wastewater Treatment Plant's commitment to safety as written in their Safety Goal and respect for the hazards associated with the handling and storage of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, WWTP personnel enthusiastically strive to find and implement opportunities to reduce the risks associated with the use of these chemicals while maintaining effluent water quality and protection of the environment.
